Subject: Re: [cantera] reactor and equilibrate
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387; y=jODPXjG-iu_8TFfvjrRaTvwNufH3pYXnwqGtS0xPgK4p
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

Jeff,

In either Python or MATLAB, you can use the "try" command to catch 
exceptions thrown by Cantera and continue execution.  You can specify 
the max number of iterations when you call equilibrate. Also you can 
specify an error tolerance. The default is a very strict error 
tolerance.  You can probably set it to a much higher value without 
significant loss of accuracy.
You might also compare the performance of the two solvers by supplying 
the parameter "solver = 1" or "solver = 2".  Look at the example 
"stoich.py" in the Python demos/equilibrium folder for an example of 
how to choose the solver and specify parameters.

Dave


On Jun 30, 2005, at 3:16 PM, csmnofbobs wrote:

> Dr. Goodwin,
> I am trying to use reactor1 to calculate the time it takes for a
> mixture of N2O and C2H6 to reach equilibrium.  To do this, I use
> equilibrate(gas,HP) to determine the equilibrium molar mass for a
> given set of input conditions, and then have reactor iterate until
> the molar mass of the gas is within 1% of this value and record the
> end time.  I have a loop set up to run this procedure at many
> different temperatures and save all the data in an excell file.  The
> problem is that equilibrate often returns the "no convergence in 1000
> iterations" error, which stops all the calculations and keeps the
> data from being saved.  It is puzzling because equilibrate only
> sometimes returns the error.  If I run equilibrate over and over
> without changing any of the input conditions, it sometimes reaches a
> solution, and sometimes returns the error.  It seems that I either
> need some way to increase the maximum number of iterations, or a way
> to tell Cantera to rerun equilibrate until it reaches a solution, as
> opposed to stopping entirely.  Are either one of these options
> possible?
> Thank you very much, and have a great Independence Day.
> Jeff Miller
